questionListItems.title: What is the definition of an endowment fund?

answer.body: An endowment is a fund set up to generate income for a certain purpose, such as to support the organisation’s activities and programmes. If the endowment fund is set up exclusively for charitable purposes, it should be registered as a charity.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What are the requirements stipulated under the Charities Act/ Regulations to register a charity in Singapore?

answer.body:
An organisation must first be established as a legal entity before it can apply for registration as a charity with the Office of the COC. To qualify, the applicant must meet the following requirements:

 

a)     The purposes or objects of the organisation must be exclusively charitable;

b)     The organisation must have at least three governing board members, of whom at least two must be Singapore citizens or permanent residents; and

c)     The purposes or objects of the organisation must be beneficial wholly or substantially to the community in Singapore.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

answer.body:
We recognise the following as charitable purposes:

  • relief of poverty,

  • advancement of education,

  • advancement of religion, or

  • other purposes beneficial to the community, such as:

    • the advancement of health;

    • advancement of sport where the sport promotes health through physical skill and exertion;

    • the advancement of citizenship or community development;

    • the advancement of arts, heritage or science;

    • the advancement of environmental protection or improvement;

    • the relief of those in need by reason of youth, age, ill-health, disability, financial hardship or other disadvantages;

    • the advancement of animal welfare.

 

Please note that fund-raising is not a charitable object.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Can a charity conduct incidental activities?

answer.body: An organisation may conduct incidental activities if it supports the advancement of its charitable purpose. For example, fund-raising itself is not a charitable purpose but the organisation can conduct fund-raising appeal to raise funds for its programmes.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Will an organisation which carries out for-profit activities; where part of the profit are channeled to charitable purposes (i.e. welfare fund for the needy), qualify to register as a charity?

answer.body: Only organisations with exclusively charitable purposes will qualify to apply for charity status.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Who are the governing board members of a charity?

answer.body: Governing board members are persons responsible for the general control and management of an organisation. The governing board is collectively responsible to ensure compliance with the organisation’s governing instrument and all relevant laws and regulations. The governing board also makes sure that the organisation is well governed and operates responsibly so that the organisation would continue to be effective, credible and financially sustainable.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Who can qualify to be a board member of a charity?

answer.body:
The governing board must ensure that the individuals appointed to the governing board are eligible to act as governing board members, such as:      

 

(a) Not disqualified as a governing board member pursuant to section 28(1) of the Charities Act. For instance, the individual should not be an undischarged bankrupt or not been convicted of an offence ** involving dishonesty or terrorism, terrorist financing or money laundering.

(b) Not removed by the Commissioner of Charities from any capacity following an inquiry.

 

**Under the Registration of Criminals Act, to qualify for a record to be spent, the person must not have been sentenced to an imprisonment term exceeding three (3) months or to a fine not exceeding $2,000. The person must also satisfy a five (5) year crime free period amongst other criteria. An individual may check the spent status of his/her criminal record via the Singapore Police Force E-Services Portal.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What are the general responsibilities of governing board members?

answer.body:
Governing board members must:


  • Act in the best interest of the charity and be actively involved in the management and decision-making process of the charity;

  • Stay true to the charitable purpose(s) and objects and abide by the rules set out in the charity’s governing instrument;

  • Ensure proper management of the charity by establishing good governance practices and strong internal controls for proper accountability and transparency;

  • Ensure that the charity complies with the legislative requirements, including filing the annual returns on time.


Visit the Charity Portal for more details on the Governing Board’s Duties and Responsibilities.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Who must register as a charity?

answer.body:
As long as an organisation/trust/foundation is set up for exclusively charitable purposes and carries out activities to achieve these purposes, it must register the organisation/trust/foundation as a charity within three (3) months of its establishment.

 

**Stipulated under Section 7(8)(a) of the Charities Act, it is the duty of the governing board members of any charity which is not registered nor excepted from registration to apply to be registered, and to supply the documents and information required by subsection (7) within 3 months after its establishment or such longer period as the Commissioner may in his discretion allow.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Can an organisation apply for charity status beyond three months of its establishment?

answer.body: Any qualifying organisation set up for exclusively charitable purposes should apply for charity status as soon as possible.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: How do I register a charity?

answer.body: The application for charity status can be submitted via the Charity Portal. The applicant would require a valid Singpass or Corppass account to login to the Charity Portal to submit the application.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What are the documents required for charity registration?

answer.body:
Please submit the charity application online via the Charity Portal and furnish the following documents:

i)               Certified true copy of the Governing Instrument;

ii)              Certified Statements of Accounts for the last 3 years (if applicable); and

iii)             2-year activity and fund disbursement plan.

 

**Please refer to the Charity Portal for the Checklist for Application for Registration as a Charity for more guidance on how to complete the charity application.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

answer.body:
A governing instrument is a formal document setting out the key provisions regarding the administration of an organisation such as the charitable purposes, composition of the governing board, how meetings will be held, etc. The type of governing instrument depends on the legal structure the organisation is set up as.

 

Additionally, the governing instrument is also known as a:

  • Constitution (for charities set up as Companies Limited by Guarantee or Societies);

  • Trust instrument (for charities set up as Trust); or

  • Rules and Regulations (for charities set up as Funds).

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What are the provisions generally included in the governing instrument of a charity?

answer.body:
The governing instrument should generally include standard rules and clauses relating to:

  • The organisation’s charitable purpose(s);

  • Governing board members;

  • Conflict of Interest Policy;

  • Quorum for Meeting;

  • Trustees for Immovable Property (applicable for society charities);

  • Amendments to Governing Instruments; and

  • Dissolution or Cessation of Charity Status.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What should the 2-year activity and fund disbursement plan consist of? Is there a specific format that applicants need to follow?

answer.body:
For the 2-year activity plan, it should include relevant information about the programmes/initiatives/activities that the organisation intends to carry out in furtherance of the purposes stated in the governing instruments. The fund disbursement plan would typically include the projected income which the organisation expects to receive; the projected disbursements for the programmes/initiatives/activities and the expenditures which the organisation expects to incur in the next 2 to 3 years, as a result of carrying out the said programmes/initiatives/activities.

 

Please refer to the “2-year activity and fund disbursement plan template” available on the Charity Portal >> Registering as a charity > Checklist for Application for Registration as a Charity for reference.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore
